title: History of Bayesian Theory
content: The ideas behind Bayesian statistics were developed by the Reverend Thomas Bayes, an 18th-century English statistician, philosopher, and Presbyterian minister. His work was posthumously published in 'An Essay towards solving a Problem in the Doctrine of Chances' (1763). However, it was Pierre-Simon Laplace who independently developed and popularized what is now known as Bayes' theorem.

title: What is Bayes' Theorem?
content:
Bayes' theorem is a mathematical formula for determining conditional probability. It describes the probability of an event, based on prior knowledge of conditions that might be related to the event. The formula is:

P(A|B) = [P(B|A) * P(A)] / P(B)

  • P(A|B) is the posterior probability: the probability of hypothesis A given the data B.
  • P(B|A) is the likelihood: the probability of data B given that the hypothesis A is true.
  • P(A) is the prior probability: the probability of hypothesis A being true, before any evidence.
  • P(B) is the marginal likelihood: the probability of the data B under any hypothesis.

title: Example: Medical Diagnosis
content:
Imagine a patient is tested for a rare disease that affects 1% of the population. The test is 99% accurate (i.e., it correctly identifies 99% of people with the disease and 99% of people without it). If a patient tests positive, what is the probability they actually have the disease?

Using Bayes' theorem, we can calculate that the probability is only about 50%. This is because the number of false positives from the healthy population is much larger than the number of true positives from the small diseased population.

title: Example: Spam Filtering
content: Bayesian filters are a popular technique for email spam filtering. The filter learns from a training set of emails that have been manually classified as spam or not spam. When a new email arrives, the filter uses Bayes' theorem to calculate the probability that the email is spam, based on the words it contains.
